quotes: The Turkish government offered her Turkish citizenship, which she received from the Turkish foreign minister on 11 October 2012, tracing her family origin to Karaman Province in Central Anatolia.
In 2012, Karman participated as a panelist in the annual Clinton Global Initiative session titled 'Champions of Action'.
In 2019, she was honored as the Social Entrepreneur of the Year at The Asian Awards.
On 17 December 2020, Karman reported that Houthi rebels raided her home and office, taking control of both locations after looting them.

Tawakkol Karman co-founded the human rights group Women Journalists Without Chains (WJWC) with seven other female journalists in 2005 in order to promote human rights, 'particularly freedom of opinion and expression, and democratic rights.'
In 2007, WJWC released a report that documented Yemeni abuses of press freedom since 2005.
In 2009, she criticised the ministry of information for establishing trials that targeted journalists.

organizations.name: Women Journalists Without Chains

organizations.name: Female Reporters Without Borders
quotes: Although it was founded as 'Female Reporters Without Borders,' the present name was adopted in order to get a government license.

organizations.name: Ministry of Information
quotes: Karman has said she has received 'threats and temptations' and was the target of harassment from the Yemeni authorities by telephone and letter because of her refusal to accept the Ministry of Information's rejection of WJWC's application to legally create a newspaper and a radio station.

organizations.name: Bilakoyood
quotes: After a governmental review of the text services, the only service that was not granted a license to continue was Bilakoyood, which belonged to WJWC and had operated for a year.

organizations.name: Saudi-UAE-led coalition
quotes: From her new home in Istanbul, she continues to speak out against injustices in Yemen, including the war waged by the Saudi-UAE-led coalition and U.S. drone attacks.

The Turkish government offered her Turkish citizenship, which she received from the Turkish foreign minister on 11 October 2012, tracing her family origin to Karaman Province in Central Anatolia.
The Turkish government offered her Turkish citizenship, which she received from the Turkish foreign minister on 11 October 2012, tracing her family origin to Karaman Province in Central Anatolia.
From her new home in Istanbul, she continues to speak out against injustices in Yemen, including the war waged by the Saudi-UAE-led coalition and U.S. drone attacks.
Like many Yemenis, Karman was forced to leave Yemen after the Houthi takeover of the capital, Sana'a, due to the worsening security situation.
